The  Project  will  (i)  upgrade  and  construct  about  41.4  kilometers  (km) 
of two-lane border access roads from inland clearance depots (ICDs) 
at  the  southern  border  of  Nepal  at  major  gateways  in  Birganj  and  in 
Bhairawa to artery highways; (ii) build a new ICD of about 7.5 hectares 
at the major gateway of Kakarbita at the eastern border of Nepal; (iii) 
purchase and install a wide area network (WAN), install the automatic 
system of customs data (ASYCUDA) in the selectivity module and on 
a  pilot  basis  in  the  brokers  module,  and  adjust  procedures  of  the  
accounting/bookkeeping  modules;  and  (iv)  build  institutional  capacity 
to  ensure  efficient  and  effective  installation  of  the  additional  modules 
and 
to  support  policy  reforms.  The  Project  will  help  recover 
maintenance  cost  for  the  border  access  roads  by  placing  appropriate 
tolls  on  the  upgraded  roads,  promote  public-private  partnership  by 
privatizing  terminal  operation  of  the  proposed  ICD  at  Kakarbita,  and 
enhance  governance  capacity  by  providing  facilities  of  fast  and 
transparent customs clearance and reducing opportunities of financial 
irregularities. The Project will lessen the vulnerability of local people to 
human immunodeficiency virus/acquired immunodeficiency syndrome 
(HIV/AIDS)  and  human  trafficking  across  the  border  by  waging  a 
participatory  and  awareness  campaign  and  by  providing  necessary 
physical  ICD  facilities  in  the  proposed  ICD  with  respect  to  preventing 
human trafficking.

Given  the  critical  role  of  transit  logistics  and  trade  facilities  in 
integrating Nepal’s economy into subregional and global markets, the 
Government’s priority is to upgrade governance capacity and physical 
infrastructure  to  improve  reliability  of  goods  delivery,  and  reduce 
transport costs and goods clearing time, particularly along the corridor 
from Kathmandu to Kolkata and Haldia  ports in India, and the corridor 
from  Kathmandu  to  Khulna  and  Mongla  and  Chittagong  ports  in 
Bangladesh. The Transport Working Group is deliberating on broader 
issues  with  respect  to  trade  and  transit  agreements  and  customs 
cooperation  among  Bangladesh,  Bhutan,  India  and  Nepal.  The 
proposed  improvements  of  border  transit  logistics  and  trade  facilities 
under the Project form part of two key subregional corridors involving 
Nepal, along which complementary investment initiatives are being or 
will  be  undertaken  by  Bangladesh,  Bhutan,  India  and  Nepal  and 
supported  by  ADB.  The  Project  is  fully  in  line  with  the  Government’s 
10th Five-Year Plan to improve the country’s subregional connectivity 
and  economic  integration.  The  Project  is  a  result  of  consultation  with 
subregional  countries  and  complements  ongoing  and  prospective 
projects along the key corridors.  
 
The project objective is to help the Government integrate the economy 
into  the  subregion’s.  The  Project  is  an  integral  part  of  the  ADB-
supported  SASEC  program  to  promote  subregional  cooperation 
through upgraded governance capacity, better transport facilities, and 
more efficient and effective trade management.  
 
The total project cost is estimated at $26.7 million equivalent, including 
interest  charges  during  construction.  The  foreign  exchange  cost  is

Subregional  economic  cooperation  emerged  as  a  stepping-stone  to  broader  regional 
cooperation  in  the  late  1990s.  The  South  Asia  Subregional  Economic  Cooperation  (SASEC)2 
program  identified  six  priority  areas  for  economic  cooperation:  transport;  energy;  environment; 
tourism; information and communications technology; and trade, investment, and private sector 
cooperation.  In  February  2004,  the  SASEC  Transport  Working  Group  (TWG)  established  that 
system -wide impediments (choke points) to cross-border cargo movements along key transport 
corridors in the subregion needed to be removed, such as (i) long and costly supply chains for 
inbound  and  outbound  goods;  (ii)  inadequate  infrastructure  and  cumbersome  customs 
procedures; (iii) substandard traffic management at the borders, ineffective communications and 
cargo  tracking  systems,  and  costly  empty backhaul  practices;  and  (iv)  lack  of  a  risk-based 
cargo-sampling system. Transit route arrangements should be rationalized.  
 
  The  Islamabad  Declaration  adopted  at  the  12th  Summit  for  South  Asia  Association  for

promoting  regional  cooperation  and  economic  integration.  The  scheduled  removal  of  tariff  and 
nontariff trade and investment barriers contained in the South Asia Free Trade Area (SAFTA) 3 
agreement  signed  at  the  summit  is  expected  to  open  up  vast  opportunities  for  trade  and 
investment  growth.  ADB  is  working  with  SAARC  and  SASEC  to  promote  subregional 
cooperation to upgrade the transport network and to improve policies and institutional capacity. 
SASEC countries, on their own initiative and supported by ADB, are rationalizing and simplifying 
transit and trade agreements through SASEC and SAARC mechanisms.

Nepal's transport infrastructure mainly consists of roads and civil aviation. Roads carry 
about 90% of all passengers and freight within the country. A key part of Nepal's road system is 
the  4,856  km  Strategic  Road  Network  (SRN).  The  national  highways  consist  of  the  East-West 
Highway  (EWH)  and  north-south  highways  linking  major  towns  that  serve  much  of  the 
population. The EWH goes from Gaddachauki at the west border with India, to Kakarbita at the 
east  border  with  India,  runs  the  length  of  the  country  in  the  terai,  and  is  connected  through 
north-south  links  to  Kathmandu.  The  Tribhuvan  highway  is  also  vital,  and  connects  Birganj  at 
the southern border  with  India,  the  country’s  most  important  trade  border,  where  50%  of  the 
country’s trade passes through, to Kathmandu. Still, Nepal continues to lag behind its neighbors 
in road infrastructure, with an estimated road network of low density—about 90 meters (m) per 
square km or 660 m per 1,000 people. The several sections on the present access road from 
Birganj  ICD  to  Tribhuvan  highway  through  Padam  road  are  congested  and  encroached  and 
cannot carry the heavy traffic from the Birganj ICD. A shortcut access road is proposed under 
the Project to improve border accessibility. Cargo traffic between Kathmandu and the Bhairawa 
ICD, where about 10% of  the country’s trade passes,  has to go north to Butwal to connect to 
EWH,  29%  longer  than  an  existing  shortcut  gravel  road,  which  will  be  widened  and  upgraded 
under the Project.

In  Nepal,  the  Heavy  Vehicle  Act  limits  truck  axle  loads  to  10.2  tons,  although 
enforcement is not strict.  Trucks with capacity greater than 16 tons or carrying containers are 
generally taken no further than Birganj. Instead, the cargo is then transferred and unstuffed at 
Birganj  onto  10–12  ton  capacity  Nepalese  registered  vehicles.  About  50%  of  Nepal-bound 
containers  are  handled  at  Haldia,  and  50%  at  Kolkata.  Nepal-bound  bulk  cargo  is  almost 
exclusively  handled  at  Haldia,  and  about  90%  of  this  is  moved  on  to  Nepal  by  rail,  usually 
bagged.  Nepalese  vehicles  may  move  without  hindrance  to  Indian  railheads,  but  need 
permission  from  the  Indian  embassy  in  Kathmandu  to  travel  further  and  are  prohibited  from

stays.  For  Nepal-Bangladesh  trade,  Nepali  trucks  need  to  be  convoyed  within  India  by  Indian 
authorities and stop at Fulbari (India)/Banglabandha (Bangladesh). Bangladesh vehicles cannot 
enter India. Nepal private operators dominate the road freight transport industry, mostly through 
truckers’ associations. Freight haulage rates vary by road condition. In some cases the rate per 
ton-km for freight on unpaved roads is 100% higher than for paved roads.

Nepal’s economy is highly reliant on foreign trade2. Nepalese trade experienced double-
4.

($2,421 million) and the trade deficit reached NRs74, 422 million ($1,034 million), representing a

boosted growth in total imports. Nepal’s largest export commodity is garments ($165.1 million, 
23.8%  of  its  total  export  value),  followed  by  carpets  ($73.9  million)  and  Jute  goods  ($26.4 
million). Correspondingly, the largest import commodity is basic manufactures ($484.6 million), 
followed by machines and transport equipment ($287.5 million) and mineral fuels ($277 million).  
 
5.

based  both  in  terms  of  product  composition  and  market  orientation.  The  principal  Nepalese 
imports from India are higher-value goods such as textiles, medicines, vehicles and machinery, 
as well as low value bulk goods including rice, cement and coal.
